Title: Spoofing the Human User External Entity
Description: Human User may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Meta Quest 2. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
Inferrable data types:
PII
Sytem fingerprint data
VR sensory data
VR input data
VR output data
Application data
Financial data
Social activity
Logging & auditing

Title: Spoofing the Human User External Entity
Description: Human User may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to unauthorized access to Meta Quest Touch controllers. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.

Title: Data Flow networked_content Is Potentially Interrupted
Description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.

Title: XML DTD and XSLT Processing
Description: If a dataflow contains XML, XML processing threats (DTD and XSLT code execution) may be exploited.
Inferrable data types:
PII
Sytem fingerprint data
VR sensory data
Application data
Financial data
Social activity
Logging & auditing

Title: Data Flow networked_telemetry Is Potentially Interrupted
Description: An external agent interrupts data flowing across a trust boundary in either direction.

Title: Potential Process Crash or Stop for Server
Description: Server crashes, halts, stops or runs slowly; in all cases violating an availability metric.

Title: Cross Site Scripting
Description: The web server 'Server' could be a subject to a cross-site scripting attack because it does not sanitize untrusted input.
Inferrable data types:
PII
Sytem fingerprint data
VR sensory data
Application data
Financial data
Social activity
Logging & auditing

Title: Weak Authentication Scheme
Description: Custom authentication schemes are susceptible to common weaknesses such as weak credential change management, credential equivalence, easily guessable credentials, null credentials, downgrade authentication or a weak credential change management system. Consider the impact and potential mitigations for your custom authentication scheme.

Title: External Entity Network device Potentially Denies Receiving Data
Description: Network device claims that it did not receive data from a process on the other side of the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.
Inferrable data types:
PII
Sytem fingerprint data
VR sensory data
Application data
Financial data
Social activity
Logging & auditing

Title: Spoofing of the Network device External Destination Entity
Description: Network device may be spoofed by an attacker and this may lead to data being sent to the attacker's target instead of Network device. Consider using a standard authentication mechanism to identify the external entity.
Inferrable data types:
PII
Sytem fingerprint data
VR sensory data
Application data
Financial data
Social activity
Logging & auditing

Title: XML DTD and XSLT Processing
Description: If a dataflow contains XML, XML processing threats (DTD and XSLT code execution) may be exploited.
Inferrable data types:
PII
Sytem fingerprint data
VR sensory data
Application data
Financial data
Social activity
Logging & auditing

Title: Elevation by Changing the Execution Flow in Server
Description: An attacker may pass data into Server in order to change the flow of program execution within Server to the attacker's choosing.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Meta Quest 2 may be able to impersonate the context of Network device in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Collision Attacks
Description: Attackers who can send a series of packets or messages may be able to overlap data. For example, packet 1 may be 100 bytes starting at offset 0. Packet 2 may be 100 bytes starting at offset 25. Packet 2 will overwrite 75 bytes of packet 1. Ensure you reassemble data before filtering it, and ensure you explicitly handle these sorts of cases.

Title: Replay Attacks
Description: Packets or messages without sequence numbers or timestamps can be captured and replayed in a wide variety of ways. Implement or utilize an existing communication protocol that supports anti-replay techniques (investigate sequence numbers before timers) and strong integrity.

Title: Replay Attacks
Description: Packets or messages without sequence numbers or timestamps can be captured and replayed in a wide variety of ways. Implement or utilize an existing communication protocol that supports anti-replay techniques (investigate sequence numbers before timers) and strong integrity.

Title: Collision Attacks
Description: Attackers who can send a series of packets or messages may be able to overlap data. For example, packet 1 may be 100 bytes starting at offset 0. Packet 2 may be 100 bytes starting at offset 25. Packet 2 will overwrite 75 bytes of packet 1. Ensure you reassemble data before filtering it, and ensure you explicitly handle these sorts of cases.

Title: Potential Data Repudiation by Server
Description: Server claims that it did not receive data from a source outside the trust boundary. Consider using logging or auditing to record the source, time, and summary of the received data.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Server may be able to impersonate the context of Network device in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Meta Quest 2 may be able to impersonate the context of Human User in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Meta Quest 2 may be able to impersonate the context of Meta Quest Touch controllers in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Meta Quest Touch controllers may be able to impersonate the context of Meta Quest 2 in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Elevation Using Impersonation
Description: Meta Quest Touch controllers may be able to impersonate the context of Human User in order to gain additional privilege.

Title: Server May be Subject to Elevation of Privilege Using Remote Code Execution
Description: Network device may be able to remotely execute code for Server.
Justification: It is assumed the network device is not sophisticated enough
